content.raw: Oops, we totally overlooked the fact that simspark uses +Y for the front instead of +X.
content.html: Oops, we totally overlooked the fact that simspark uses +Y for the front instead of +X.

update.description:
This pull request suggests merging the robot model similar to one that is used in Simsaprk namely NAO_Type_Zero. Its description can be found in the [wiki](#!/osrf/robocup3ds/wiki/Robot%20Model) of the project . 
For testing the model, please run a RoboCup agent which can be found in this[ link](https://feupload.fe.up.pt/get/3HeAVUD1hq2UcGf).

Alternatively it is possible to run UTVilla agents can be succesfully loaded onto the field (download from [here](http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~AustinVilla/sim/3dsimulation/AustinVilla3DSimulationFiles/2015/binary/utaustinvilla.tar.bz2)). Please use ./start_penalty_kicker.sh or ./start.sh to run a single agent or eleven agents respectively.
update.title: Simspark robot model

content.raw: to control the robot, we need high PID feedback gains. Using "Command limit = 1000.0", the robot was not kept upright.
content.html: to control the robot, we need high PID feedback gains. Using "Command limit = 1000.0", the robot was not kept upright.

content.raw: I could not control the ElbowRoll properly using 1000 hz ODE, so I decrease their PID, it means this joint are not very stiff. if the robot works with 2000 hz ODE, the user can assign the P and D value up to 160 to increase the stiffness of the joint.
content.html: I could not control the ElbowRoll properly using 1000 hz ODE, so I decrease their PID, it means this joint are not very stiff. if the robot works with 2000 hz ODE, the user can assign the P and D value up to 160 to increase the stiffness of the joint.

content.raw: In my test, this set of PID parameters controls the simspark model stably.
content.html: In my test, this set of PID parameters controls the simspark model stably.

content.raw: The height of Simspark model was decreased a bit after its body part properties had been tuned.
content.html: The height of Simspark model was decreased a bit after its body part properties had been tuned.

update.description:
This pull request suggests merging the robot model similar to one that is used in Simsaprk namely NAO_Type_Zero. Its description can be found in the [wiki](#!/osrf/robocup3ds/wiki/Robot%20Model) of the project . 
For testing the model and seeing functional robot please install the Nima_Integration branch. Then run a RoboCup agent which can be found in this[ link](https://feupload.fe.up.pt/get/ze9pt8Y2qUwhHce) by the following command and the robot should walk stably.
```
#!linux

./fcpagent -u 7
```
Alternatively if the agent can not be run on your machine because of different OS, install the code form this [link](https://feupload.fe.up.pt/get/jAFSOuzXHvUqokg) and follow its ReadME to spawn the agent on the simulator.
update.title: Simspark robot model

content.raw:
@nima_sh , the changes are looking much better, the model is almost exactly the same as that on the simspark sheet. Basically what I'm doing to find forgotten offsets is to look at the model in Gazebo with an orthogonal view and at the schematics at the same time. You can see a few little parts are still slightly different.

Once the collisions are all matching, we should check the same for the joints.

I hope all these changes make the model behave better with your walking controller!

![collisions2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/893336980-collisions2.png)
content.html:
@nima_sh , the changes are looking much better, the model is almost exactly the same as that on the simspark sheet. Basically what I'm doing to find forgotten offsets is to look at the model in Gazebo with an orthogonal view and at the schematics at the same time. You can see a few little parts are still slightly different.

Once the collisions are all matching, we should check the same for the joints.

I hope all these changes make the model behave better with your walking controller!

content.raw:
I think the X and Y measurements are swapped, no? Shouldn't it be:

`<size>0.070 0.080 0.11</size>`
content.html:
I think the X and Y measurements are swapped, no? Shouldn't it be:

<size>0.070 0.080 0.11</size>

content.raw: We're missing a 0.005 offset on X here
content.html: We're missing a 0.005 offset on X here

content.raw: fixed in rev. c602cd3
content.html: fixed in rev. c602cd3

content.raw: fixed in rev c602cd3.
content.html: fixed in rev c602cd3.

content.raw:
Oh I actually meant 5mm (0.005). I'm guiding myself by the schematics, it is subtle, but the joints are there. Check it out:

![pitch.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/2315546308-pitch.png)
content.html: Oh I actually meant 5mm (0.005). I'm guiding myself by the schematics, it is subtle, but the joints are there. Check it out:

content.raw:
You mean -0.05 offset on Z?  
the "head pitch" joint position before the change: ![BeforeChange.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/1616105082-BeforeChange.png)
and the joint position after the change: ![afterchange.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/3225481895-afterchange.png)
I did not know about this option ;), even the aldebaran NAO model does not specify the joints positions.
content.html:
You mean -0.05 offset on Z?
the "head pitch" joint position before the change: and the joint position after the change: I did not know about this option ;), even the aldebaran NAO model does not specify the joints positions.

content.raw: Cool, we're almost there! I only saw a couple of weird offsets in collisions and started looking at joint poses.
content.html: Cool, we're almost there! I only saw a couple of weird offsets in collisions and started looking at joint poses.

content.raw: Actually a lot of joints seem to be missing their offsets. Let me know if you need help with that ;)
content.html: Actually a lot of joints seem to be missing their offsets. Let me know if you need help with that ;)

content.raw:
I think the `HeadPitch` joint needs a -0.005 offset on Z.

You can add a `<pose>0 0 -0.005 0 0 0</pose>` element to the joint, the pose is with respect to the child link.
content.html:
I think the HeadPitch joint needs a -0.005 offset on Z.

You can add a <pose>0 0 -0.005 0 0 0</pose> element to the joint, the pose is with respect to the child link.

content.raw: I think we don't need the X offset on forearm collisions, right? It's pushing the collision to the tip of the arms, away from the biceps, you can see it by looking from the side
content.html: I think we don't need the X offset on forearm collisions, right? It's pushing the collision to the tip of the arms, away from the biceps, you can see it by looking from the side

content.raw: I think we're missing a 0.005 offset on X on the tibias
content.html: I think we're missing a 0.005 offset on X on the tibias

content.raw: I am not very sure about the elbow joints and Elbow configuration. with the ODE step size 0.001 the joint is not controllable while with ODE step_size 0.0005 is controllable, I reduce its joints <effort> limits.
content.html: I am not very sure about the elbow joints and Elbow configuration. with the ODE step size 0.001 the joint is not controllable while with ODE step_size 0.0005 is controllable, I reduce its joints <effort> limits.

content.raw: Fixed in rev 03b242a.
content.html: Fixed in rev 03b242a.

update.description:
This pull request suggests merging the robot model similar to one that is used in Simsaprk namely NAO_Type_Zero. Its description can be found in the [wiki](#!/osrf/robocup3ds/wiki/Robot%20Model) of the project . 
For testing the model and seeing functional robot please install the Nima_Integration branch. Then run a RoboCup agent which can be found in this[ link](https://feupload.fe.up.pt/get/ze9pt8Y2qUwhHce) by the following command and the robot should walk stably.
```
#!linux

./fcpagent -u 7
```
Alternatively if the agent can not be run on your machine because of different OS, install the code form this [link](https://feupload.fe.up.pt/get/jAFSOuzXHvUqokg) and follow its ReadME to spawn the agent on the simulator.
update.title: Simspark robot model

content.raw:
I'm taking a look at the collisions and trying to figure out why some of them seem to be in a different position from the schematics above. I found some offsets inside collision elements which might be part of the reason. Take a look at these screenshots. (Tip: choose orthogonal view on the top toolbar where you can change the view angle)

![collisions.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/707895362-collisions.png)

![collision2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/2264051415-collision2.png)
content.html: I'm taking a look at the collisions and trying to figure out why some of them seem to be in a different position from the schematics above. I found some offsets inside collision elements which might be part of the reason. Take a look at these screenshots. (Tip: choose orthogonal view on the top toolbar where you can change the view angle)

content.raw: Do we need this offset in the collision? I think it would be better to keep all collisions without offsets, so their poses match the links' inertial properties. What do you think?
content.html: Do we need this offset in the collision? I think it would be better to keep all collisions without offsets, so their poses match the links' inertial properties. What do you think?
